Description: Fragment of marble bead-and-reel moulding with the end of a dart above. Two beads and two reels of the astragal are preserved and located in an obtuse angle. On the relief ground traces of applied red paint are visible, as well as blue colour on the underside of the moulding. The surface of a dart, which points between two reels, is fractured, as is the curved edge of the right adjoining leaf. The fragment is made of a grey and glazed marble.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'second temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: The reconstructed dimension between the axes is 11,20 cm. Traces of the cyma suggested an Ionic cyma rather than a Lesbian, even though the traces on the surface have great similarity with the corner fragment B 410 (Altekamp). There is therefore not sufficient evidence for a precise allocation. Published (Koenigs 2007, 329 Cat. 13; Petrie 1886, 14 No. 18, Pl. 14 A; Altekamp 138 No. 2)
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B415)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XIV A, left)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (no. 13, p. 329, pl. 14)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.22) (Phase 3)
